### I. INTUITION: What the upper bound `max(x,max(forbidden))+b+a` means
Once we are able to perform a backward jump (`-b`) in the the "simple" region `(max(x,max(forbidden)), infinity)`, we no longer need to jump forward (`+a`).

### II. OBSERVATIONS
#### 1. Order does not matter
First, if we ignore the forbidden points, a path `p` only needs to satify the condition that displacement `d(p[0...N]) == m*a-n*b == target`. Give `m` and `n`, any permutation with no consecutive `-b` jumps forms a valid path. This is obviously not true if the path crosses `[min(forbidden), max(forbidden)]`, but we can just focus on the (potentially empty) subpath that lies within the "simple" region `(max(forbidden), infinity)` where this property still holds.

#### 2. If you overshoot the target, you eventually need to jump back
Consider a path `p` that intersects `(x, infinity)`, then for any `p[i...N]` where `p[i] > x` we have the displacement `d(p[i...N]) == m*a-n*b == x-p[i] < 0`. To make things simpler, we can move the boundary further to`X := max(x, max(forbidden)) >= x` and consider a subpath `p[i...N]`  where `p[i] > X`. We still have `d(p[i...N]) == m*a-n*b == x-p[i] < 0`, but since we are now in the "simple" region, we can utilize the commutativity of jumps.

#### 3. Paths that are too spread out can always be shrinked
This is what we shall prove.

Consider the **first** `p[i]` that intersects `(X+b+a, infinity)`:

* By definition, the first `-b` jump starts at some `p[j] > p[i] > X+b+a` and ends at `p[j+1] == p[j]-b > X+a`. After the transformation, it would start at `p'[i-1] == p[i-1] > X+b` and end at `p'[i] == p'[i-1]-b > X` . That is, the reordering happens within the "simple" region.
* Finally, it can be shown that such rearrangement won't result in consecutive `-b` jumps.

So from `p'[i-1]` in `(X+b, X+b+a]`, instead of jumping into `(X+b+a, infinity)`, we can always jump back first to `p'[i] == p'[i-1]-b` in `(X, X+a]`, and then jump forward to `p'[i+1] == p'[i]` in `(X+a, X+2*a]`. 

After reordering one pair of `+a` and `-b`, the number of jumps is unchanged, but the size of the subpath intersecting `(X+b+a, infinity)` is shrinked by 2. We can repeat this process until no point lies beyonds `X+b+a`.

The tricky situations start to happen when `if a < b`. In this situation you can start to use combinations of +a and -b where you have the net result to walk backwards through the number line regardless of the limit on how many times in a row you can go backwards. If you ignored forbidden, then the furthest you ever need to go to create the walk back effect is `MAX = x + a + b` anything beyond that would potentially still be valid work, but it is unnecessary.

Now if you do factor in the forbidden and you have a forbidden value that is out beyond x, you now have to use +a and -b to dance around a forbidden value that is now trying really hard to get in the way. So now to exceed this new artificial problem its not enough to just look at `MAX = x + a + b`, you now how to go out beyond the biggest possible forbidden value `MAX = max(forbidden) + a + b` before you can reasonably assume you exhausted all options and we are wasting time.

### I. INTUITION: What the upper bound `max(x,max(forbidden))+b+a` means
Once we are able to perform a backward jump (`-b`) in the the "simple" region `(max(x,max(forbidden)), infinity)`, we no longer need to jump forward (`+a`).

### II. OBSERVATIONS
#### 1. Order does not matter
First, if we ignore the forbidden points, a path `p` only needs to satify the condition that displacement `d(p[0...N]) == m*a-n*b == target`. Give `m` and `n`, any permutation with no consecutive `-b` jumps forms a valid path. This is obviously not true if the path crosses `[min(forbidden), max(forbidden)]`, but we can just focus on the (potentially empty) subpath that lies within the "simple" region `(max(forbidden), infinity)` where this property still holds.

#### 2. If you overshoot the target, you eventually need to jump back
Consider a path `p` that intersects `(x, infinity)`, then for any `p[i...N]` where `p[i] > x` we have the displacement `d(p[i...N]) == m*a-n*b == x-p[i] < 0`. To make things simpler, we can move the boundary further to`X := max(x, max(forbidden)) >= x` and consider a subpath `p[i...N]`  where `p[i] > X`. We still have `d(p[i...N]) == m*a-n*b == x-p[i] < 0`, but since we are now in the "simple" region, we can utilize the commutativity of jumps.

#### 3. Paths that are too spread out can always be shrinked
This is what we shall prove.

### III. PROOF: Given a path that intersects  `(X+b+a, infinity)`, there exists a path of equal length that lies within `[0, X+b+a]`:

Consider the **first** `p[i]` that intersects `(X+b+a, infinity)`:
* By definition `p[i]` can only be reached from `p[i-1]` in `(X+b, X+b+a]` by a `+a` jump. 
* Similarly, because `b > a`, `p[i-1]` can only be reached from `p[i-2]` by a `+a` jump, otherwise `p[i-2] == p[i-1]+b > X+b+b > X+b+a`, a contradiction (`p[i]` is supposed to be the first). 
* For subpath `p[i-1...N]`, we have `m*a-n*b == d(p[i-1...N]) == x-p[i-1] < x-(X+b) <= -b`. Reordering the terms, we get `n > 1`, i.e. there is at least one `-b` jump in `p[i-1...N]`. We can move the **first** `-b` jump  to the start of the jump sequence. 
* By definition, the first `-b` jump starts at some `p[j] > p[i] > X+b+a` and ends at `p[j+1] == p[j]-b > X+a`. After the transformation, it would start at `p'[i-1] == p[i-1] > X+b` and end at `p'[i] == p'[i-1]-b > X` . That is, the reordering happens within the "simple" region.
* Finally, it can be shown that such rearrangement won't result in consecutive `-b` jumps.

So from `p'[i-1]` in `(X+b, X+b+a]`, instead of jumping into `(X+b+a, infinity)`, we can always jump back first to `p'[i] == p'[i-1]-b` in `(X, X+a]`, and then jump forward to `p'[i+1] == p'[i]` in `(X+a, X+2*a]`. 

After reordering one pair of `+a` and `-b`, the number of jumps is unchanged, but the size of the subpath intersecting `(X+b+a, infinity)` is shrinked by 2. We can repeat this process until no point lies beyonds `X+b+a`.  

Q.E.D.

mean?

mean?

When I fisrst saw this task, I was surprised that it has such a low acceptance rate. After I attempted to solve it, I know why. People get rejected with TLE.

I have approached this using BFS with keeping `state(position, canJumpBack)`. But I was getting TLE.
It was obvious that the problem was due to position getting too large. I initially set the upper bound to a * x, but for the problem constraints it will be 4 000 000. This caused TLE on test cases where the is no solution.

title: Distribute Repeating Integers
question_content:
You are given an array of n integers, nums, where there are at most 50 unique values in the array. You are also given an array of m customer order quantities, quantity, where quantity[i] is the amount of integers the ith customer ordered. Determine if it is possible to distribute nums such that:

  • The ith customer gets exactly quantity[i] integers,
  • The integers the ith customer gets are all equal, and
  • Every customer is satisfied.

Return true if it is possible to distribute nums according to the above conditions.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [1,2,3,4], quantity = [2]
Output: false
Explanation: The 0th customer cannot be given two different integers.

Example 2:

Input: nums = [1,2,3,3], quantity = [2]
Output: true
Explanation: The 0th customer is given [3,3]. The integers [1,2] are not used.

Example 3:

Input: nums = [1,1,2,2], quantity = [2,2]
Output: true
Explanation: The 0th customer is given [1,1], and the 1st customer is given [2,2].

 

Constraints:

  • n == nums.length
  • 1 <= n <= 105
  • 1 <= nums[i] <= 1000
  • m == quantity.length
  • 1 <= m <= 10
  • 1 <= quantity[i] <= 105
  • There are at most 50 unique values in nums.

solutions.content:
# **1. Bitmask -- from numbers to customers**
The core of the problem is that, given a specific integer `x` (means that there is a number occuring `x` times in the input), how can we know which subset of customers it should be distributed to. Say, `x` = 10, and `quantity=[6,4,5, 9]`, then we can assign 10 to `6,4`, `4,5`, or just any single `4`, `5`, `6`,  `9` . So we use a bit-mask to iterate all possible combinations for each integer, and see if we can satisfy all customers. 

The basic algorithm is that
* we will iterate through all bitmasks for the first integer
* and for each mask, iterate through all of its submasks for the second integer
* and for each mask, iterate through all of its submasks for the third integer
* ...
* If there is submasks that satisfies all customers (all bits being set, etc), then it's true.



**Iterate a subset of a bit mask is like**
```
for (int m=0; m<(1<<n); ++m)
    for (int s=m; s; s=(s-1)&m)
 ... s and m ...
 ```

But what's the complexity? Let's first consider a simple situation that there is only 2 integers -- 2 levels of submask, which is shown in the above code.

---

Let's prove that the inner loop will execute a total of O(3^n) iterations.

Proof:
* Consider the i-th bit. There are exactly three options for it:
	1. it is not included in the mask m (and therefore not included in submask s),
	2. it is included in m, but not included in s, or
	3. it is included in both m and s.


As there are a total of n bits, there will be 3^n different combinations.

---
It is similar to see that when there is m levels, then for each bit, there will be (m+1) status (either picked by any level or not picked at all).

So the complexity would be (m+1)^n.

---

For the specific problem, we can have an optimization that, we only need at most the first n largest integers (if n < m). SO the complexity is (min(m,n)+1)^n


```python
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], Q: List[int]) -> bool:
        cnt = collections.Counter(nums)
        avai = sorted([*cnt.values()])[-len(Q):]
        Q.sort(reverse=True)
        n = len(Q)
        @lru_cache(None)
        def is_ok(i, ns):
            needed = 0
            for j in range(n):
                if (1<<j) & ns:
                    needed += Q[j]
            return needed <= avai[i]
        # 1 is waiting, 0 is satisfied
        @lru_cache(None)
        def dfs(i, status):
            if i == len(avai) or status == 0:
                return status == 0
            if dfs(i+1, status):
                return True
            ns = status # need customer to be feeded as 1 bit
            while ns:
                if is_ok(i, ns) and dfs(i+1, ns^status):
                    return True
                ns = (ns - 1) & status
            return False
        return dfs(0, (1<<n)-1)
```
		



# 2. **Backtracking -- from customers to numbers**

Instead of thinking how a kind of number can be distributed to different combination of customers, we can think about which number will a customer pick.

To do this, for each customer, we simply iterate over all possible numbers that can satisfy this customer and continue to the next customer.
In worst case, for each customer (n totally), we have m choice, so the time complexity is O(m^n).
But since the amount of data is small, that we can sort the numbers and use memorization to optimize it.
A sample python code:

```python
def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], Q: List[int]) -> bool:
    cnt = collections.Counter(nums)
    avai = sorted([*cnt.values()])[-len(Q):]
    Q.sort(reverse=True)
    n = len(Q)
    @lru_cache(None)
    def dfs(cid, avai):
        """
        cid: customer_id
        """
        if cid == len(Q):
            return True
        for i in range(len(avai)):
            if avai[i] >= Q[cid]:
                new_avai = avai[:i]+avai[i+1:]
                if avai[i] > Q[cid]:
                    new_avai += (avai[i] - Q[cid]),
                if dfs(cid+1, tuple(sorted(new_avai, reverse=True))):
                    return True
        return False
    return dfs(0, tuple(avai[::-1]))
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
We know we only have 10 customers at worst. We also know we have at most 50 unique items in our set up. We can backtrack on the customers and on the items, and can limit ourselves to only as many items as we have customers if we go in greatest reversed order of items present. This lets us limit ourselves appropriately to a space at worst of 10^10. We can allow ourselves to stop early by utilizing a backtracking string to target the current items and current customers as a key, thus letting us memoize results and reduce computational time altogether. 

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Find your number of items, your number of customers, and then check to make sure you at least have enough items to match customers before any combinations. 

Then, get the frequency of your items. 
Turn nums into the sorted form of the frequencies (not the items, the frequencies) in reverse order for as many as you have customers. This lets you focus on a subset of size 10^10 at worst. 

Sort your quantities in reverse. 

If your sum of item frequencies is less than the sum of your quantity, you can also return False already. 

Otherwise, set up a memo 

During the backtracking phase, pass in the current items, customer index, and current customer statuses 
- Build a backtrack key using the items sorted | customer status sorted as a string 
- If your customer index is past the total number number of customers, set memo at backtrack key to true and return true 
- If you have the backtrack key in the memo, return what you found already and skip the preprocess. This is the reason for the sorting as it combines similar set ups with different location strings. 
- otherwise, get the current amount as quantity at customer index 
- set your current item index to 0 
- while your current item index is in range of your current items length 
    - if the item here is not big enough -> move forward by 1 until it is 
    - otherwise 
        - if the current item index is greater than 0 and we have matching items here 
            - go until the last version of these if you can 
            - if you end up out of range, break 
            - otherwise if you end up at a bad spot, move forward one and continue 
        - otherwise try to use the current item to satisfy the current customer, updating in both lists appropriately 
        - make a temp key of doing so 
        - if you have seen this temp key and it doesn't work 
            - unset what you did and move forward one and continue 
        - if you saw it and it did work 
            - set memo for the backtrack key and return True 
        - otherwise, go check it out
            - then update the memo
            - if it was true, update memo for backtrack key and return 
            - otherwise, undo the look, move forward and continue 
- if you never got a success in the loop, update the memo here and return False 

To solve, kick off backtrack with nums, 0, quantity           

# Complexity
- Time complexity : O (Sum m! / (i!(m-i)!) for i in range 1, m-1, where m is number of customers)
    - O(10^10) at worst since we do 10^10 considerations in our backtracking is the naive amount 
    - However, we can limit down since our sort for the backtrack keys worked (never caused an error) to O(3629822) operations, since we now know that we are dealing with combinatory states where no repeats are allowed and order doesn't matter (otherwise, the backtrack keys would have caused a problem). Due to this, we get the time complexity of combinations with no repeats instead of permutations with repeats for the backtrack process.   
    - This puts our overall time complexity in the form of O(Sum m!/(i!(m-i)!) for i in range 1, m-1), where m is the number of customers according to the problem statement. For comparison sakes, this is about 2750 times faster than O(10^10)

- Space complexity : Due to backtracking nature, we match our space complexity unfortunately, but due handidly beat the space in the other case due to our size reduction. If someone is interested, this can potentially be done in bottom up form and save us the massive amounts of space with the time savings. 

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool :
        '''
            at most 50 unique values in the array 
            customer quantities -> no more than 10 customers -> m 
                                -> each customer can order between 1 and 10^5, the number of items range as well 
            nums -> amount of items 
            want to distribute nums so that 
                each customer gets exactly customer_i items (so if there are not exactly i items not gonna work)
                the integers that compose the ith customer order are all equal and sum to customer i items 
                every customer can be satisfied 
        
        '''
        # get number of items and number of customers 
        number_of_items = len(nums)
        number_of_customers = len(quantity) 
        # before doing frequency work, if you do not have enough items, you'll never satisfy everyone 
        if number_of_items < number_of_customers : 
            return False 
        # find out your frequency of your items 
        frequency_of_items = collections.Counter(nums)
        # and limit yourself to the best for your customers 
        nums = sorted(frequency_of_items.values(), reverse=True)[:number_of_customers]
        quantity.sort(reverse = True)
        # if you still can't satisfy everyone, don't try and return False 
        if sum(nums) < sum(quantity) : 
            return False 
        # set up a memo to track your progress 
        self.memo = dict() 

        def backtrack(current_items, customer_index, current_customers) :
            # set up a backtrack key where you use the sorted form of each to capture as many possible alternate substates as you can 
            backtrack_key = "".join([str(c_it) for c_it in sorted(current_items)]) + "-" + "".join([str(c_c) for c_c in sorted(current_customers)]) 
            # if you reached the end, mark it and return True. Otherwise, if you've seen this, return what you already found! 
            if customer_index == number_of_customers : 
                self.memo[backtrack_key] = True
                return True 
            elif backtrack_key in self.memo : 
                return self.memo[backtrack_key]

            # figure out how much you have 
            current_amount = quantity[customer_index]

            # consider all your items 
            c_i = 0 
            while c_i < len(current_items) :
                # if we have an item that is gte here  
                if current_items[c_i] >= current_amount :
                    # if we are past 0 and have a matching situation  
                    if c_i > 0 and current_items[c_i] == current_items[c_i - 1] :
                        # go until you run out of room, or until you run out of matches, or until you run into a problem  
                        while c_i < len(current_items) and current_items[c_i] == current_items[c_i - 1] and current_items[c_i] >= current_amount : 
                            c_i += 1 
                        # if you ran out of room, nothing to do here, break 
                        if c_i >= len(current_items) : 
                            break 
                        elif current_items[c_i] < current_amount :
                            # otherwise, if you ran out items, skip on to the next  
                            c_i += 1 
                            continue  
                    # otherwise, if you have not run out room, and you do have an item worth looking at 
                    # look at it 
                    current_items[c_i] -= current_amount
                    current_customers[customer_index] = 0 
                    # get the key 
                    temp_key = "".join([str(c_it) for c_it in sorted(current_items)]) + "-" + "".join([str(c_c) for c_c in sorted(current_customers)])
                    # check if you have it and it doesn't work 
                    if temp_key in self.memo and self.memo[temp_key] == False :
                        # if it doesn't, unset the looking and then move forward one  
                        current_items[c_i] += current_amount
                        current_customers[customer_index] = current_amount
                        c_i += 1 
                        continue 
                    elif temp_key in self.memo and self.memo[temp_key] == True : 
                        # if you have the key and it worked already, skip out of there after resetting your backtrack key as well 
                        self.memo[backtrack_key] = True
                        return True 
                    elif temp_key not in self.memo : 
                        # otherwise if we have not seen this thing, set up a temp result and lock it in 
                        temp_result = backtrack(current_items, customer_index + 1, current_customers) 
                        self.memo[temp_key] = temp_result 
                        if temp_result == True : 
                            # on success, update and return 
                            self.memo[backtrack_key] = True 
                            return True 
                        else : 
                            # on failure, unset and continue 
                            current_items[c_i] += current_amount 
                            current_customers[customer_index] = current_amount
                            c_i += 1 
                            continue 
                else : 
                    c_i += 1 
                    continue 

            # if you ran out of room or weren't able to make it work -> set False and return it 
            self.memo[backtrack_key] = False
            return False 
        
        # kick it off with our altered nums and quantities 
        return backtrack(nums, 0, quantity)
```

```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums, quantity):
        n, m = len(nums), len(quantity)

        dict1 = collections.Counter(nums)

        quantity.sort(reverse = True)

        def dfs(i):
            if i == m:
                return True 

            for key,val in dict1.items():
                if val >= quantity[i]:
                    dict1[key] -= quantity[i]

                    if dfs(i+1):
                        return True

                    dict1[key] += quantity[i]

            return False 

        return dfs(0)



            



        



        
        
        
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
This can be approached as a DFS problem with memoization and greedy search space reduction.

First, one should observe the recursive property of the problem: A customer comes and wants a certain amount of equal integers. There might be mutliple equal integers we could give him, which the changes the equal integers we can give the next customer.

So we need a recursion, that has as input the current customer we are dealing with and which are left and the amount of equal integers we have left. The customers that are left can be coded as a pointer into the customer array. The amount of equal integers ist more difficult. At first, on can realize that we count the amount of equal integers per integer, but it does not really matter which customer gets which integer, it is only important how many we have of those. E.G. if we have four 4's and four 3's our recursive relation does not care or change if we give the customer 4s or 3s. Therefore we can code our state of integers left as a dict, that tells us we have: 3 equal integers two times for the example above.

We can then use these two things (count of equal integers and pointer into the customer array) to make a unique key for a state. Also that state repeats so we can add memoization to not compute problems again. I use a frozenset over the items of our counter dict as a pythonic and fast way to make a hashable tuple from the dict.

The second thing one needs to figure our is that we can decrease our search space much faster by dealing with difficult customers first (the ones wanting a whole lot of equal numbers), as there are only a few possibilities of those, which reduces the number of splits at the beginning of our recursion tree.

The problem really needs some time to figure out. Maybe try to look at my code. I myself was really surpised, I figured this out
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
The approach includes memoization, state coding and search space reduction
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
I haven't figured it out yet, please let me know if you have an idea.
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
I haven't figured it out yet, please let me know if you have an idea.
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool:

        # count the amount of same integers
        cn = collections.Counter(collections.Counter(nums).values())
        
        # sort the customers to deal with the most difficult ones first
        quantity.sort(reverse=True)

        # make recursive dfs with memoization
        cache = dict()
        def dfs(items, idx):
            if idx >= len(quantity): return True
            tp_it = frozenset(items.items())
            if (tp_it, idx) not in cache:

                # go though all the frequent items
                result = False
                for qnti, nq in list(items.items()):
                    
                    # check whether we have similar integers
                    if not nq or qnti < quantity[idx]: continue

                    # update our items
                    items[qnti] -= 1
                    items[qnti-quantity[idx]] += 1

                    # recurse deeper
                    if dfs(items, idx+1):
                        result = True
                        break

                    # undo changes to items
                    items[qnti] += 1
                    items[qnti-quantity[idx]] -= 1
                
                # set the cache
                cache[(tp_it, idx)] = result
            return cache[(tp_it, idx)]
        return dfs(cn, 0)

                    



```

```
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool:

        # count the amount of same integers
        cn = collections.Counter(collections.Counter(nums).values())
        
        # sort the customers to deal with the most difficult ones first
        quantity.sort(reverse=True)

        # make recursive dfs with memoization
        cache = dict()
        def dfs(items, idx):
            if idx >= len(quantity): return True
            tp_it = frozenset(items.items())
            if (tp_it, idx) not in cache:

                # go though all the frequent items
                result = False
                for qnti, nq in list(items.items()):
                    
                    # check whether we have similar integers
                    if not nq or qnti < quantity[idx]: continue

                    # update our items
                    items[qnti] -= 1
                    items[qnti-quantity[idx]] += 1

                    # recurse deeper
                    if dfs(items, idx+1):
                        result = True
                        break

                    # undo changes to items
                    items[qnti] += 1
                    items[qnti-quantity[idx]] -= 1
                
                # set the cache
                cache[(tp_it, idx)] = result
            return cache[(tp_it, idx)]
        return dfs(cn, 0)
```

```py
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums, quantity):
        """
            observations:
                at most 50 unique values in nums
            
            distribute the asked quantity of nums to query
            
            now for a queery like:
                [1,1,1,1,2,2,2]  q = [1, 4] , we cant take query1 "1" out from  list of 1, bcz if we do, 1 remains = 3 and we wont be able to fulfil 2nd query q2 = "4", 
                
            I think we can be a lil greedy and always give away the lowest fulfilling char so we have 3 "2" and 4 "1" so we fulfil any query less than 3 using 2 
                    
        """
        
        """
        s = SortedList([(c, num) for num, c in Counter(nums).items()])
        s1 = s.copy()
        n = len(s)
        quantity.sort(reverse=True)
        
        
        
        for q in quantity:
            i = s.bisect_left((q, 0))
            if i >= n:
                return False # cant fill this query
            curr_c, curr_elem = s.pop(i)
            if curr_c < q:
                return False # cant fill
            elif curr_c == q:
                # exact match
                s.add((0, curr_elem)) # no more left
            else:
                s.add((curr_c - q, curr_elem))
        
        return True
        """
        """
        ^ code doesnt work for the case
        
        [1,1,2,2,1]
        [2,2,1]
        
        which was actually last test case L.. But idea being the hypothesis that give the lowest count element first doesnt stand true, we need look ahead, i.e DP
        
        bounded sequence donot matter dp ( we need tuple)
        
        dp(?)
        states
        state transition
        base
        """
        quantity.sort(reverse=True)
        counts = Counter(nums)
        
        
        def dp(qi, c):
            
            
            if qi == len(quantity):
                return True
            
            needed_elems = quantity[qi]
            
            for i in c:
                if c[i] >= needed_elems:
                    
                    c[i] -= needed_elems
                    if dp(qi+1, c) == True:
                        return True
                    c[i] += needed_elems
            
            return False
    
        return dp(0, counts)
```

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/85fd017c-b649-4e50-821f-6dd1895f8d57_1633447604.9101381.jpeg)
```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], Q: List[int]) -> bool:
        same_items = sorted(Counter(nums).values())
        m, n = len(Q), len(same_items)
        masks = [sum(Q[i] for i in range(m) if mask & 1<<i) for mask in range(1<<m)]  # I call entries of this array "Q_sums"
        valids = set()   # These are the bitmasks that correspond to possible maps same_items[idx] --> Q[i] for all i in mask
        winner = (1<<m) - 1
        for idx in range(n):
            new_valids = set()
            for mask, x in enumerate(masks):
                if same_items[idx] >= x:
                    if mask == winner: return True
                    new_valids.add(mask)
            for x in valids.copy():
                for y in new_valids:
                    if x & y == 0: 
                        merged_mask = x | y
                        if merged_mask == winner: return True
                        valids.add(merged_mask)
            valids.update(new_valids)            
        return False
        # It seems like what I want to check for is if same_items has enough items to distribute across Q
        # So, from indices of same_items, we generate bitmasks saying which objects of Q that we are covering
        # Thus, a valid bitmask for same_items[idx] is one whose Q_sum <= same_items[idx].
        # Further, each entry of Q cannot cannot receive items from different same_items[idx]. Hence, two compatible
        # bitmasks x, y are s.t. x & y == 0. 
        # Therefore, we return true iff we encounter the bitmask (1<<m) - 1 (eg 11111 if m = 5)
        
        # We propagate bitmasks by first finding all valid masks for same_items[0]. Then we find all valid masks for same_items[1].
        # We keep a set of valid masks encountered so far, since it's possible that a valid distribution of items from same_items does 
        # not involve all items in same_items (as the picture I drew illustrates). Then, for same_items[idx] we put valid masks
        # in new_valids, and then for each entry in new_valids, we loop over valids and toss in compatible masks. Continue until see winner or loop ends.
```

```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], Q: List[int]) -> bool:
        same_items = sorted(Counter(nums).values())
        m, n = len(Q), len(same_items)
        masks = [sum(Q[i] for i in range(m) if mask & 1<<i) for mask in range(1<<m)]  # I call entries of this array "Q_sums"
        valids = set()   # These are the bitmasks that correspond to possible maps same_items[idx] --> Q[i] for all i in mask
        winner = (1<<m) - 1
        for idx in range(n):
            new_valids = set()
            for mask, x in enumerate(masks):
                if same_items[idx] >= x:
                    if mask == winner: return True
                    new_valids.add(mask)
            for x in valids.copy():
                for y in new_valids:
                    if x & y == 0: 
                        merged_mask = x | y
                        if merged_mask == winner: return True
                        valids.add(merged_mask)
            valids.update(new_valids)            
        return False
        # It seems like what I want to check for is if same_items has enough items to distribute across Q
        # So, from indices of same_items, we generate bitmasks saying which objects of Q that we are covering
        # Thus, a valid bitmask for same_items[idx] is one whose Q_sum <= same_items[idx].
        # Further, each entry of Q cannot cannot receive items from different same_items[idx]. Hence, two compatible
        # bitmasks x, y are s.t. x & y == 0. 
        # Therefore, we return true iff we encounter the bitmask (1<<m) - 1 (eg 11111 if m = 5)
        
        # We propagate bitmasks by first finding all valid masks for same_items[0]. Then we find all valid masks for same_items[1].
        # We keep a set of valid masks encountered so far, since it's possible that a valid distribution of items from same_items does 
        # not involve all items in same_items (as the picture I drew illustrates). Then, for same_items[idx] we put valid masks
        # in new_valids, and then for each entry in new_valids, we loop over valids and toss in compatible masks. Continue until see winner or loop ends.
```

solutions.content:
It doesn't matter what the contents of num are. So tracking the count of each item in nums is sufficient. Going one step further, we can maintain a count of counts and  update the counter while backtracking.

```
from collections import Counter

class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool:
        def backtrack(i, cntr):
            if i == len(quantity):
                return True
            
			# cnt is the number of times some element is occuring in the array.
			# If we use one of those nums, decrement the count of that num count
			# Now the number of elems in the bucket we chose would have decreased and
			# this new count needs to be added to the counter
			# If the number of buckets of  some count becomes zero, remove it from the counter
			# If backtrack returns False, just reverse these operations
			# A temp counter is necessary for these operations because we are changing the size of the original counter
			temp_counter = cntr.copy()
            for cnt in cntr:
                if cnt >= quantity[i]:
                    temp_counter[cnt] -= 1
                    if temp_counter[cnt] == 0:
                        temp_counter.pop(cnt)
                    rem = cnt - quantity[i]
                    temp_counter[rem] += 1
                    
                    if backtrack(i+1, temp_counter):
                        return True
                    
                    temp_counter[rem] -= 1
                    if temp_counter[rem] == 0:
                        temp_counter.pop(rem)
                    temp_counter[cnt] += 1
                    
            return False
        
        count_of_counts = Counter(Counter(nums).values())
        quantity.sort(reverse=True)
        return backtrack(0, count_of_counts)
```

solutions.content:
First, sort the quantity in the descending order, so we always try to serve the largest needs first, then apply as below: 

**The sequence of the principles of being greedy: **

1. for the current largest need, if we find a repeat frequency just equal to this need, then we serve 
2. for the current largest need, if there are any other needs with the same needed amount, then we try to find the largest combinational sum of these needs with the same amount, if there is any repeat frequency matched, then we serve 
3. for the current largest need, find the largest repeat frequency that can satisfy this need, if there is no, then return false. if there is, subtract the need, put the rest back to the repeat frequency pool 

So just iterate over the need values array until the end 


```Scala
  def canDistribute(nums: Array[Int], quantity: Array[Int]): Boolean = {
    val sq = quantity.sortWith(_ >= _)
    import scala.collection.mutable.HashMap
    import java.util.TreeMap
    val stats = new HashMap[Int, Int]()
    val map = new TreeMap[Int, Int]((a: Int, b: Int) => -Integer.compare(a, b))
    nums.foreach(x => stats.put(x, stats.getOrElse(x, 0) + 1))
    stats.values.foreach(x => map.put(x, map.getOrDefault(x, 0) + 1))

    var i = 0
    while (i < sq.length) {
      val v = sq(i)
      if (map.isEmpty) return false
      val maxKey = map.firstKey()
      if (maxKey < v) return false

      var j = i
      while (j < sq.length && v == sq(j)) j += 1
      j -= 1
      while (j >= i) {
        val sum = (j - i + 1) * v
        if (map.containsKey(sum)) {
          map.put(sum, map.get(sum) - 1)
          if (map.get(sum) == 0) map remove sum
          i = j + 1
        } else if (i == j) {
          val remain = maxKey - v
          map.put(maxKey, map.get(maxKey) - 1)
          if (map.get(maxKey) == 0) map remove maxKey
          if (remain != 0) map.put(remain, map.getOrDefault(remain, 0) + 1)
          i += 1
        }
        j -= 1
      }
    }
    true
  }
```

solutions.content:
complexity analysis:
* preparing v and f would take O(N)
* max depth of recursion is m
	* for each resurion there is loop O(unique values)
		* for each loop processing cost at max O(3*unique values)
*  Total number of call to recursive funtion m*(unique values)
		
**hence time complexity will be O(N)+(3m(unique values^2))(unique values)m=O(3m^2(unique values^3))**

Im really doubtfull at my complexity analysis will be thankful if u would help me to arrive at correct one if mine is wrong.



```
import bisect

class Solution:
    def toDistribute(self,values,freq,index,quantity):
        if index>=len(quantity):
            return True
        start=bisect.bisect_left(values,quantity[index])
        for i,val in enumerate(values[start:],start):
            if freq[i]==0:
                continue
            try:
                pos=values.index(val-quantity)
                freq[i]-=1
                freq[pos]+=1
                if self.toDistribute(values,freq,index+1,quantity):
                    return True
                freq[i]+=1
                freq[pos]-=1
                
            except:
                pos=bisect.bisect(values,val-quantity[index])
                freq[i]-=1
                temp_v=values[:pos]+[val-quantity[index]]+values[pos:]
                temp_f=freq[:pos]+[1]+freq[pos:]
                if self.toDistribute(temp_v,temp_f,index+1,quantity):
                    return True
                freq[i]+=1
        return False
    

    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool:
        val=collections.Counter(nums).values()
        freq=collections.Counter(val)
        v=list(freq.keys())
        v.sort()
        f=[]
        for val in v:
            f.append(freq[val])
        return self.toDistribute(v,f,0,quantity)
        
```

solutions.content:
Approach: (click to show) 1. Count how many times each number appears in nums. (this is the frequency of the number) 2. Start at the first customer i = 0 and for all frequencies grater than quantity[0] try using that number to satisfy customer i. 3. When you use frequency[j] to satisfy customer i, subtract quantity[i] from frequency[j] to show quantity[i] of that number was used. 4. Move on to the next customer (i += 1) and repeat the process until all customers are satisfied (True) or no path is found (False).
Optimizations: (click to show) 1. If the frequency of a number exactly matches a value in quantity, use it and remove that value from quantity. i.e. nums = [4, 4, 2, 3] ; quantity = [2, 2] use [4, 4] immediately so nums = [2, 3] and quantity = [2] 2. Sort quantity in reverse order (largest to smallest) so that we address the larger cusomer requests first. This helps identify False answers faster. 3. Do not try to use the same frequency twice when looking at the remaining numbers. used keeps track of the frequencies tired already for quantity[i]. 4. Use a priority queue (heap) so that if a solution exists we will arrive at it sooner and can stop early. This helps identify True answers faster.
```python def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool: # 1. Find the frequency of each number freq = collections.Counter(list(collections.Counter(nums).values())) # 2. If the quantity[i] is in freq, use that number. # i.e. quantity = [2, 2] ; nums = [1, 1, 2, 3] use [1, 1] right away # so we get quantity = [2] and nums = [2, 3] removed = set() for i in range(len(quantity)): if freq[quantity[i]] > 0: freq[quantity[i]] -= 1 removed.add(i) quantity = [quantity[i] for i in range(len(quantity)) if i not in removed] if not quantity: return True freqs = sum(([key]*freq[key] for key in freq), []) # 3. Sort the quantities in reverse order, this helps identify False cases much faster. quantity.sort(reverse = True) # 4. Breadth First Search q = [(0, freqs)] while q: i, freqs = heapq.heappop(q) i = -i if i == len(quantity): return True quant = quantity[i] used = set() # keep track of the freqs[j] values used for quantity[i] for j in range(len(freqs)): if freqs[j] >= quant and freqs[j] not in used: # do not use the same value more than once for quantity[i] used.add(freqs[j]) if freqs[j] > quant: heapq.heappush(q, (-(i+1), freqs[:j] + [freqs[j]-quant] + freqs[j+1:])) else: heapq.heappush(q, (-(i+1), freqs[:j] + freqs[j+1:])) # freqs[j] == quantity[i] we can stop checking other frequencies break return False ```
Here is a more efficient implementation: (click to show) So in the first solution the frequency of each number is stored in a list. i.e. nums = [1, 1, 1, 2, 4, 4, 5, 5] ; freqs = [3, 1, 2, 2] It is more efficient to store freqs as a counter instead. i.e. freqs = {3: 1, 1: 1, 2: 2} Because a counter: 1. uses less space when there are many repeat values 2. can be updated in O(1) time and 3. we can check if quantity[i] is in freqs in O(1) time. However, the python heapq module does not play nice with counters because Counters are not comparable. i.e. is Counter({3:1, 2:3, 1:1}) greater than Counter({2:1, 1:1, 3:3})? Python doesn't know... To use a counter with a heap, we a custom heap class that ignores the Counter part of an item when comparing items in the heap. i.e. item1 = ( 5, Counter({1:1, 2:2}) ) ; item2 = ( 3, Counter({7:1, 1:2}) ). is item1 > item 2? Yes, because 5 > 3 and ignore the Counter.
Solution: (click to show) ```python class Solution: def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool: # 1. Find the frequency of each number freqs = collections.Counter(list(collections.Counter(nums).values())) # 2. If the quantity[i] is in freq, use that number. # i.e. quantity = [2, 2] ; nums = [1, 1, 2, 3] use [1, 1] right away # so we get quantity = [2] and nums = [2, 3] removed = set() for i in range(len(quantity)): if freqs[quantity[i]] > 0: freqs[quantity[i]] -= 1 removed.add(i) quantity = [quantity[i] for i in range(len(quantity)) if i not in removed] if not quantity: return True # 3. Sort the quantities in reverse order, this helps identify False cases much faster. quantity.sort(reverse = True) # 4. Breadth First Search q = Max_Heap([(0, freqs)]) while not q.is_empty(): i, freqs = q.heappop() if i == len(quantity): return True quant = quantity[i] if quant in freqs and freqs[quant] > 0: new_freqs = freqs.copy() new_freqs[quant] -= 1 q.heappush((i+1, new_freqs)) continue for f in freqs: if f > quant and freqs[f] > 0: new_freqs = freqs.copy() new_freqs[f] -= 1 new_freqs[f-quant] += 1 q.heappush((i+1, new_freqs)) return False ```
Custom Max Heap Class: (click to show) ```python class Max_Heap(object): def __init__(self, arr): self.arr = arr if arr else [] def heappush(self, val): self.arr.append(val) i = len(self.arr) - 1 while True: i, b = self.bubble_up(i) if not b: break def heappop(self): if len(self.arr) == 1: return self.arr.pop() res = self.arr[0] self.arr[0] = self.arr.pop() i = 0 while True: i, b = self.bubble_down(i) if not b: break return res def bubble_up(self, i): if not i: return (i, False) j = (i + 1) // 2 if self.arr[j][0] < self.arr[i][0]: self.arr[i], self.arr[j] = self.arr[j], self.arr[i] return (j, True) return (i, False) def bubble_down(self, i): j = (i+1) * 2 if j - 1 >= len(self.arr): return (i, False) if j == len(self.arr): # only consider left branch if self.arr[j-1][0] > self.arr[i][0]: self.arr[i], self.arr[j-1] = self.arr[j-1], self.arr[i] return (j, False) # consider left and right branch j = max((j, j-1), key = lambda x: self.arr[x][0]) if self.arr[j][0] > self.arr[i][0]: self.arr[i], self.arr[j] = self.arr[j], self.arr[i] return (j, True) return (i, False) def is_empty(self): return not bool(self.arr) ```

solutions.title: c-o-m-3-m
python-3-dp-status-compression-solution
solutions.content:
since quantity is limited so we can use bitmap to store the status.
we only care fre of numbers in nums, thus we want to get a cnt first.
then we want to allocate each fre to each quantity.
the relation is like a typic dp problem:
dp(i,j)=dp(i-1,j) or dp(i-1,j-s) where i means we have  subarray cnt[0...j],j means we need to satisfy subquantity j. s means one sub-bit of j such that cnt[i] will satisfy s bit-map group=>sums_need(s)<=cnt[i]
eg: the final j is (1<<m)-1) which is like 11111..1111 means we want to satisfy all m numbers in quantity.
thus we want to iterate all sub-bit of j, there is a way to do that descending:sub=(sub-1)&j, which will remove leftmost 1 bit and recover all 1 after removed 1 bit, so we will get highest bit from all remain one.
then we need to compare sums of subset number and cnt[i], we can pre-calcualte it.
```
class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool:
        cnt=sorted(collections.Counter(nums).values(),reverse=True)[:len(quantity)]
        m,n=len(quantity),len(cnt)
        mask_sums=[0]*(1<<m)#pre-calculate sums of need for mask x.
        for bit in range(1,1<<m):
            for i in range(m):#add sums for each bit 1.
                if bit &(1<<i):
                    mask_sums[bit]+=quantity[i]
        
        @lru_cache(None)
        def dp(i,j):#find if exist dp(i-1,j-s) value is True or dp(i,j-s) is True
            if i<0:#no element,only True when no quantity required
                return j==0
            if j==0 or dp(i-1,j):#dp(i,j) is depend on dp(i-1,j) or any(dp(i-1,j-sub) is true)
                return True
            sub=j
            while sub!=0:
                if dp(i-1,j-sub) and cnt[i]>=mask_sums[sub]:
                    return True
                sub=(sub-1)&j   
            return False
        return dp(n-1,(1<<m)-1)

eg: the final j is (1<<m)-1) which is like 11111..1111 means we want to satisfy all m numbers in quantity.
thus we want to iterate all sub-bit of j, there is a way to do that descending:sub=(sub-1)&j, which will remove leftmost 1 bit and recover all 1 after removed 1 bit, so we will get highest bit from all remain one.
```

class Solution:
    def canDistribute(self, nums: List[int], quantity: List[int]) -> bool:
        cnt=sorted(collections.Counter(nums).values(),reverse=True)[:len(quantity)]
        m,n=len(quantity),len(cnt)
        mask_sums=[0]*(1<<m)#pre-calculate sums of need for mask x.
        for bit in range(1,1<<m):
            for i in range(m):#add sums for each bit 1.
                if bit &(1<<i):
                    mask_sums[bit]+=quantity[i]
        
        @lru_cache(None)
        def dp(i,j):#find if exist dp(i-1,j-s) value is True or dp(i,j-s) is True
            if i<0:#no element,only True when no quantity required
                return j==0
            if j==0 or dp(i-1,j):#dp(i,j) is depend on dp(i-1,j) or any(dp(i-1,j-sub) is true)
                return True
            sub=j
            while sub!=0:
                if dp(i-1,j-sub) and cnt[i]>=mask_sums[sub]:
                    return True
                sub=(sub-1)&j   
            return False
        return dp(n-1,(1<<m)-1)

title: Design an Ordered Stream
question_content:
There is a stream of n (idKey, value) pairs arriving in an arbitrary order, where idKey is an integer between 1 and n and value is a string. No two pairs have the same id.

Design a stream that returns the values in increasing order of their IDs by returning a chunk (list) of values after each insertion. The concatenation of all the chunks should result in a list of the sorted values.

Implement the OrderedStream class:

  • OrderedStream(int n) Constructs the stream to take n values.
  • String[] insert(int idKey, String value) Inserts the pair (idKey, value) into the stream, then returns the largest possible chunk of currently inserted values that appear next in the order.

 

Example:

Input
["OrderedStream", "insert", "insert", "insert", "insert", "insert"]
[[5], [3, "ccccc"], [1, "aaaaa"], [2, "bbbbb"], [5, "eeeee"], [4, "ddddd"]]
Output
[null, [], ["aaaaa"], ["bbbbb", "ccccc"], [], ["ddddd", "eeeee"]]

Explanation
// Note that the values ordered by ID is ["aaaaa", "bbbbb", "ccccc", "ddddd", "eeeee"].
OrderedStream os = new OrderedStream(5);
os.insert(3, "ccccc"); // Inserts (3, "ccccc"), returns [].
os.insert(1, "aaaaa"); // Inserts (1, "aaaaa"), returns ["aaaaa"].
os.insert(2, "bbbbb"); // Inserts (2, "bbbbb"), returns ["bbbbb", "ccccc"].
os.insert(5, "eeeee"); // Inserts (5, "eeeee"), returns [].
os.insert(4, "ddddd"); // Inserts (4, "ddddd"), returns ["ddddd", "eeeee"].
// Concatentating all the chunks returned:
// [] + ["aaaaa"] + ["bbbbb", "ccccc"] + [] + ["ddddd", "eeeee"] = ["aaaaa", "bbbbb", "ccccc", "ddddd", "eeeee"]
// The resulting order is the same as the order above.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 1000
  • 1 <= id <= n
  • value.length == 5
  • value consists only of lowercase letters.
  • Each call to insert will have a unique id.
  • Exactly n calls will be made to insert.

solutions.content:
```
class OrderedStream:

    def __init__(self, n: int):
        self.data = [None]*n
        self.ptr = 0 # 0-indexed 

    def insert(self, id: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
        id -= 1 # 0-indexed 
        self.data[id] = value 
        if id > self.ptr: return [] # not reaching ptr 
        
        while self.ptr < len(self.data) and self.data[self.ptr]: self.ptr += 1 # update self.ptr 
        return self.data[id:self.ptr]
```

solutions.content:
The idea behind this problem is simple but the description is confusing.
So let me explain a bit.

Basically , we need to store every incoming value at the given index. And 
with every incoming index, we have to check

* If the current index is less than the incoming index, the we have to return
    an empty list

* Else , we have to return an sliced list from the incoming index to the first index
    where there is no insertion till yet.

Solution:
* Initialize a list of size n with None
* Maintain the current index with self.ptr
* For every insert call, with idKey, value 
    * Assign the list[idKey-1] to the value # Since array is 0-index reduce 1
    * Check if the current index is less than incoming index(idKey-1) and return []
    * Else return sliced list from incoming index(idKey-1) till we do not encounter  None.


```
class OrderedStream:

    def __init__(self, n):
        self.stream = [None]*n
        self.ptr = 0

    def insert(self, idKey, value):
        idKey -= 1
        self.stream[idKey] = value
        if self.ptr < idKey:
            return []
        else:
            while self.ptr < len(self.stream) and self.stream[self.ptr] is not None:
                self.ptr += 1
            return self.stream[idKey:self.ptr]


# Your OrderedStream object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = OrderedStream(n)
# param_1 = obj.insert(idKey,value)
```

```
class OrderedStream:

    def __init__(self, n: int):
        self.seen = {}
        self.ptr = 1

    def insert(self, id: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
        seen, ptr = self.seen, self.ptr
        
        seen[id] = value
        result = []
        while ptr in seen:
            result.append(seen[ptr])
            del seen[ptr]
            ptr += 1
        
        self.ptr = ptr
        return result


# Your OrderedStream object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = OrderedStream(n)
# param_1 = obj.insert(id,value)
```

solutions.content:
The description as of June 13th, 2022 mentions nothing a ptr. There is a ptr that should be initialized at 1. If an item is inserted with an idKey above the ptr, return nothing. If an item is inserted that matches the ptr, return the largest chunk of contiguous values above the ptr. The ptr should update to the index immediately after the returned chunk. 

```
class OrderedStream:

    def __init__(self, n: int):
        self.ptr = 1
        self.hashmap = dict()
        

    def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
        self.hashmap[idKey] = value
        output = []
        if idKey > self.ptr:
            return output
        
        while idKey in self.hashmap:
            output.append(self.hashmap[idKey])
            idKey += 1
            self.ptr = idKey
            
        return output
```

solutions.content:
<!-- # Intuition -->
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

<!-- # Approach -->
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

<!-- # Complexity
- Time complexity: -->
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

<!-- - Space complexity: -->
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class OrderedStream {
	constructor(n) {
		this.pointer = 0;
		this.list = [];
	}

	insert(id, val) {
		let chunk = [];
		this.list[id - 1] = val;
		while (this.list[this.pointer]) {
			chunk.push(this.list[this.pointer]);
			this.pointer++;
		}
		return chunk;
	}
}
```

solutions.content:
```
class OrderedStream(object):

    def __init__(self, n):
        """
        :type n: int
        """
        self.values = [None] * n
        self.returned_min = 0
        

    def insert(self, idKey, value):
        """
        :type idKey: int
        :type value: str
        :rtype: List[str]
        """
        self.values[idKey-1] = value
        
        ret = []
		# Value not None and index in boundary of values array size
        while self.returned_min < len(self.values) and self.values[self.returned_min]:
            ret.append(self.values[self.returned_min])
			# Holding last min index returned
            self.returned_min += 1
        
        return ret
        

# Your OrderedStream object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = OrderedStream(n)
# param_1 = obj.insert(idKey,value)
```

The idea is that None value holes are skipped until filled, min boundary of the last returned non-None value is kept in `returned_min`  variable

**Method 1 - using List**

```
class OrderedStream:

    def __init__(self, n: int):
        self.n = n
        self.val = [0]*n
        self.cur = 0

    def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
        self.val[idKey-1] = value
        ans = []
        for i in range(self.cur,self.n):
            if self.val[i] == 0:
                self.cur = i
                return ans
            ans.append(self.val[i])
        return ans
```

```
        self.n = n
        self.d = {}
        self.cur = 1

    def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
        self.d[idKey] = value
        ans = []
        for i in range(self.cur,self.n+1):
            if i not in self.d:
                self.cur = i
                return ans
            ans.append(self.d[i])
        return ans
```

```
class OrderedStream:

    def __init__(self, n: int):
        self.n = n
```
```
        self.ans = []
        
        self.counter = 1

    def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
        ans = []
        heapq.heappush(self.ans, (idKey, value))
        
        x = heapq.heappop(self.ans) if self.ans else None
        while x and self.counter == x[0]:
            ans.append(x[1])
            x = heapq.heappop(self.ans) if self.ans else None
            self.counter += 1
        if x:
            heapq.heappush(self.ans, x)
        
        return ans


# Your OrderedStream object will be instantiated and called as such:
```

solutions.content:
Problem: Question is asking to return the stream of strings starting from the location **idKey**. 
Idea: Keep global variable ```self.loc```; if the idKey is equal to ```self.loc``` then return the array of strings. Otherwise return ```[]```

I hope this helps someone!
P.S.: It's better to skip this question! ;p

```
class OrderedStream:
    def __init__(self, n: int):
        self.ls = ["" for i in range(n)]
        self.loc = 0

    def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
        self.ls[idKey - 1] = value
        res = []
        
        if(self.loc == (idKey - 1)):
            while(self.loc < len(self.ls) and self.ls[self.loc] != ""):
                res.append(self.ls[self.loc])
                self.loc += 1
                
        return res
```

```
"""
exercise: 1656. Design an Ordered Stream
https://leetcode.com/problems/design-an-ordered-stream/

# Your OrderedStream object will be instantiated and called as such:

class OrderedStream:

    def __init__(self, n: int):
        self.pairs = dict()
        self.pointer = 0

    def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> list[str]:
        self.pairs[idKey] = value

        while self.pointer + 1 in self.pairs:
            self.pointer += 1

            temp.append(self.pairs[self.pointer])

        return temp


if __name__ == '__main__':

    assert os.insert(3, "ccccc").__eq__([])
    assert os.insert(1, "aaaaa").__eq__(['aaaaa'])
    assert os.insert(2, "bbbbb").__eq__(["bbbbb", "ccccc"])
    assert os.insert(5, "eeeee").__eq__([])
    assert os.insert(4, "ddddd").__eq__(["ddddd", "eeeee"])
```

exercise: 1656. Design an Ordered Stream

        self.pairs = dict()

```
def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
```
```
        self.data[idKey-1] = value           #enter value at the given idKey
        temp=[] 
        if self.data[self.ptr]==None:        #check if there's a value present at the current pointer value
            return []                                   #return empty array if yes
        else:
            while self.data[self.ptr]!=None:         #else iterate through the array until an empty slot is found
                temp.append(self.data[self.ptr])    # append all the values to temporary array "temp"
                self.ptr+=1                    
                if len(self.data)==self.ptr:              #return temp array when you reach the end of array.
                    return temp
            return temp                                       # or return temp when empty slot is found

```

solutions.content:
To be honest for a python solution we don't need to know the size of the data structure so we can simply disregard the `'n'` value for our initializer. All we really need is to set a pointer to the first position(1 per problem's constraints) & an easy place to hold our data which would be a lovely hashmap. 

	def __init__(self, n: int):
			self.ptr = 1
			self.data_holder = {}
			
For insert, just break it down into substeps:
1. Insert data. 
2. Create a list for the return of the stream. Your list will start appending from the data holder where pointer will be your key that will get incremented by 1 on each iteration. If such key is not in the data holder, then we can just return the list we have. This will aslo take care of the start position of the pointer for the next insert. 

```
def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
        self.data_holder[idKey] = value
        l = []
        while self.data_holder.get(self.ptr, False): 
            l.append(self.data_holder[self.ptr])
            self.ptr += 1 
        return l
```

Please lmk how this may be optimized or done in a more 'pythonic' like prettier way. Ty.

solutions.title: python-easy-to-understand
solutions.content:
I agree with the posters that the description here sucks, but I used the animation to arrive at the code below.

```
class OrderedStream:

    def __init__(self, n: int):
		#Like the animation, you need to maintain a pointer and an array of size n which is passed through the constructor.
        self.pointer = 0
        self.array = [None] * n

    def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
		#The idKey is 1-indexed so subtract 1 to make it 0-indexed for an array. Set the value here.
        self.array[idKey - 1] = value
        res = []
        
		#If you inserted where the pointer is pointing, now you have to loop until the pointer hits a Null value
		#in the array, or you've exhausted the array. Again, subtract 1 from the idKey to make it 0 index and start
		#concatenating your result array with each value you see at the current pointer. And that's your answer.
		#Notice that the pointer stays where you left it in this loop, don't put it back to 0 again.
        if (idKey - 1) == self.pointer:
            for i in range(self.pointer, len(self.array)):
                if self.array[self.pointer] == None:
                    break
                res.append(self.array[self.pointer])
                self.pointer += 1
        return res
```

```
class OrderedStream:

    def __init__(self, n: int):
		#Like the animation, you need to maintain a pointer and an array of size n which is passed through the constructor.
        self.pointer = 0
        self.array = [None] * n

    def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
		#The idKey is 1-indexed so subtract 1 to make it 0-indexed for an array. Set the value here.
        self.array[idKey - 1] = value
        res = []
        
		#If you inserted where the pointer is pointing, now you have to loop until the pointer hits a Null value
		#in the array, or you've exhausted the array. Again, subtract 1 from the idKey to make it 0 index and start
		#concatenating your result array with each value you see at the current pointer. And that's your answer.
		#Notice that the pointer stays where you left it in this loop, don't put it back to 0 again.
        if (idKey - 1) == self.pointer:
            for i in range(self.pointer, len(self.array)):
                if self.array[self.pointer] == None:
                    break
                res.append(self.array[self.pointer])
                self.pointer += 1
        return res
```

solutions.content:
##### Leetcode: 1656. Design an Ordered Stream.

Create pointer at the first element in the array, on each insertion move pointer until meet an empty cell. Push each non empty cell value to the answer array for a current insert call. If pointer points at the empty cell return array would be empty one.

Ruby code:
```Ruby
# Leetcode: 1656. Design an Ordered Stream.
# https://leetcode.com/problems/design-an-ordered-stream/
# Runtime: 188 ms, faster than 60.00% of Ruby online submissions for Design an Ordered Stream.
# Memory Usage: 211.2 MB, less than 46.67% of Ruby online submissions for Design an Ordered Stream.

class OrderedStream

=begin
    :type n: Integer
=end
    def initialize(n)
       
        @a = Array.new(n)
        @next = 0
        
        
    end


=begin
    :type id: Integer
    :type value: String
    :rtype: String[]
=end
    def insert(id, value)
        @a[id-1] = value
        x = []
        if @a[@next].nil?
            x = []
        else
            while ! @a[@next].nil?
                x.push(@a[@next])
                @next += 1
            end
        end
        return x
    end


end

# Your OrderedStream object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = OrderedStream.new(n)
# param_1 = obj.insert(id, value)
```

solutions.content:
1. 'yield' is a good way to return list that element needed to check, since it can save memory and save code!
2. Tail None is a stop sign for end of data, and save action of 'check if self.ptr in range'
```
# Platform: leetcode.com
# No. 1656. Design an Ordered Stream
# Link: https://leetcode.com/problems/design-an-ordered-stream/
# Difficulty: Eas
# Dev: Chumicat
# Date: 2020/11/15
# Submission: https://leetcode.com/submissions/detail/420399391/
# (Time, Space) Complexity : O(n), O(n)
#
# Your OrderedStream object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = OrderedStream(n)
# param_1 = obj.insert(id,value)
class OrderedStream:
    def __init__(self, n: int):
        self.data = [None]*(n+1)   # Use a tail None to mark end
        self.ptr = 0

    def insert(self, id: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
        self.data[id-1] = value
        while self.data[self.ptr]:
            yield self.data[self.ptr]
            self.ptr += 1
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class OrderedStream:

    def __init__(self, n: int):
        self.stream = [None] * n
        self.ptr = 0
        self.n = n

    def insert(self, idKey: int, value: str) -> List[str]:
        self.stream[idKey - 1] = value
        start = self.ptr
        while self.ptr < self.n and self.stream[self.ptr]:
            self.ptr += 1
        
        if start == self.ptr:
            return []
        else:
            return self.stream[start:self.ptr]
        


# Your OrderedStream object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = OrderedStream(n)
# param_1 = obj.insert(idKey,value)
```

You saved my time. Idk why they didn\'t point out that effing pointer.
I hope they can add your comment in the question\'s description. Lol.

***Here's my explanation***

you gotta make an *OrderedStream* class  which has a method "insert" that takes two params (idKey, stringVal) and return "List<String>"...

here is what you have to do :
[1] you should have an integer variable to "act" like a pointer, it is initially starts by 1.
[2] in each "insert", if the "idkey" is same value as the current pointer,  return "list" of strings and increment the pointer.
[3] else, return an "empty list []".


**NOTE**
- you should return a list of the all strings that come after that idkey when (idkey==pointer).


*How it would be judged*

OrderedStream os = new OrderedStream(5), and (ptr = 1)

os.insert(1,"aaaa"), since the idkey is the same as the current ptr, so return ["aaaa"], then the pointer would be 2.

os.insert(3,"cccc"), idkey is not equal to current ptr, so return [], and the pointer stays the same.

os.insert(4,"dddd"), idkey is not equal to current ptr, so return [], and the pointer stays the same.

os.insert(2,"bbbb"), since the idkey is the same as the current ptr, so return ["bbbb", "cccc", "dddd"], then the pointer would be 5.

os.insert(5,"eeee"), since the idkey is the same as the current ptr, so return ["eeee"].



hope you guys get it!
Clear and understandable explanations!
Top-1 of the ugliest problem descriptions I\'ve seen on LC so far.\n\nYou get the problem? - FAANG drying to hire you. No solution required. :)

dont read all the extra info in description. follow the image if there is a value is present where ptr is at then return the largest chunk that is existing i.e increment ptr until u read null value. make sure ptr is less than the size of the main list
If an interviewer asks you this question it\'s a red flag showing you shouldn\'t take that position
I will probably not pass if he wants it done in 10 minutes, like they usually do.

***Here's my explanation***

you gotta make an *OrderedStream* class  which has a method "insert" that takes two params (idKey, stringVal) and return "List<String>"...

here is what you have to do :
[1] you should have an integer variable to "act" like a pointer, it is initially starts by 1.
[2] in each "insert", if the "idkey" is same value as the current pointer,  return "list" of strings and increment the pointer.
[3] else, return an "empty list []".


**NOTE**
- you should return a list of the all strings that come after that idkey when (idkey==pointer).


*How it would be judged*

OrderedStream os = new OrderedStream(5), and (ptr = 1)

os.insert(1,"aaaa"), since the idkey is the same as the current ptr, so return ["aaaa"], then the pointer would be 2.

os.insert(3,"cccc"), idkey is not equal to current ptr, so return [], and the pointer stays the same.

os.insert(4,"dddd"), idkey is not equal to current ptr, so return [], and the pointer stays the same.

os.insert(2,"bbbb"), since the idkey is the same as the current ptr, so return ["bbbb", "cccc", "dddd"], then the pointer would be 5.

os.insert(5,"eeee"), since the idkey is the same as the current ptr, so return ["eeee"].

title: Determine if Two Strings Are Close
question_content:
Two strings are considered close if you can attain one from the other using the following operations:

  • Operation 1: Swap any two existing characters.
    • For example, abcde -> aecdb
  • Operation 2: Transform every occurrence of one existing character into another existing character, and do the same with the other character.
    • For example, aacabb -> bbcbaa (all a's turn into b's, and all b's turn into a's)

You can use the operations on either string as many times as necessary.

Given two strings, word1 and word2, return true if word1 and word2 are close, and false otherwise.

 

Example 1:

Input: word1 = "abc", word2 = "bca"
Output: true
Explanation: You can attain word2 from word1 in 2 operations.
Apply Operation 1: "abc" -> "acb"
Apply Operation 1: "acb" -> "bca"

Example 2:

Input: word1 = "a", word2 = "aa"
Output: false
Explanation: It is impossible to attain word2 from word1, or vice versa, in any number of operations.

Example 3:

Input: word1 = "cabbba", word2 = "abbccc"
Output: true
Explanation: You can attain word2 from word1 in 3 operations.
Apply Operation 1: "cabbba" -> "caabbb"
Apply Operation 2: "caabbb" -> "baaccc"
Apply Operation 2: "baaccc" -> "abbccc"

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= word1.length, word2.length <= 105
  • word1 and word2 contain only lowercase English letters.

determine-if-two-strings-are-close-python-counter
solutions.content:
We come to two conclusions after analisys (hints are very helpful in this case):
1. We cannot introduce new characters
2. List of counts of characters will stay consistent
```
class Solution:
    def closeStrings(self, word1: str, word2: str) -> bool:
        # Saves some time
        if len(word1) != len(word2):
            return False
        
        from collections import Counter
        counts1 = Counter(word1)
        counts2 = Counter(word2)
        
        # No new chars can appear with operations
        if counts1.keys() != counts2.keys():
            return False
        
        # Counts can be swapped, but they will stay consistent
        if sorted(counts1.values()) != sorted(counts2.values()):
            return False
        
        return True

```
solutions.code:
```
class Solution:
    def closeStrings(self, word1: str, word2: str) -> bool:
        # Saves some time
        if len(word1) != len(word2):
            return False
        
        from collections import Counter
        counts1 = Counter(word1)
        counts2 = Counter(word2)
        
        # No new chars can appear with operations
        if counts1.keys() != counts2.keys():
            return False
        
        # Counts can be swapped, but they will stay consistent
        if sorted(counts1.values()) != sorted(counts2.values()):
            return False
        
        return True

```

solutions.content:
**Basic Idea :** 

If the two strings are close, then 
* They must have the same set of characters.
* The frequency of each character in each string must be the same.


**C++ Solution**
```
	bool closeStrings(string word1, string word2) {
		if(word1.size() != word2.size()) return false; // check if the two words are of equal length
		vector<int> v1(26,0), v2(26,0); // initialise two vectors of size 26 with all entries as 0
		for(char ch: word1) v1[ch-'a']++; // count the number of each character in word1 and increment the corresponding index in v1
		for(char ch: word2) v2[ch-'a']++; // count the number of each character in word2 and increment the corresponding index in v2
		for(int i=0; i<26; i++){ // check if there is a character in word1 and not in word2 or vice versa
			if((v1[i] == 0 && v2[i] != 0) || (v1[i] != 0 && v2[i] == 0)) return false;
		}
		sort(v1.begin(), v1.end()); // sort the two vectors
		sort(v2.begin(), v2.end());
		return v1 == v2; // check if the two vectors are equal
	}
```

solutions.content:
## One line solution
```python
# Platform: leetcode.com
# No. 1657. Determine if Two Strings Are Close
# Link: https://leetcode.com/problems/determine-if-two-strings-are-close/
# Difficulty: Medium
# Dev: Chumicat
# Date: 2020/11/15
# Submission: https://leetcode.com/submissions/detail/420404393/
# (Time, Space) Complexity : O(n), O(n)
# 1. Check length for shortcut
# 2. Check set for consist of character
# 3. Check count count for consist of count
class Solution:
    def closeStrings(self, word1: str, word2: str) -> bool:
        return len(word1) == len(word2) \
            and set(word1) == set(word2) \
            and Counter(Counter(word1).values()) == Counter(Counter(word2).values())
```
## You can reuse counter to accelerate
```python
# Platform: leetcode.com
# No. 1657. Determine if Two Strings Are Close
# Link: https://leetcode.com/problems/determine-if-two-strings-are-close/
# Difficulty: Medium
# Dev: Chumicat
# Date: 2020/11/15
# Submission: https://leetcode.com/submissions/detail/420421060/
# (Time, Space) Complexity : O(n), O(n)
# 1. Check length for shortcut
# 2. Check set for consist of character
# 3. Check count count for consist of count
class Solution:
    def closeStrings(self, word1: str, word2: str) -> bool:
        if len(word1) != len(word2): return False 
        
        c1, c2 = Counter(word1), Counter(word2)   # Reuse of keys
        return c1.keys() == c2.keys() \
            and Counter(c1.values()) == Counter(c2.values())
```

## Even further
Another things that I concerned is that str.count is muck more faster than Counter. I didn't confirm which will be faster:
1. str.count check 26 times (or check set of string since we use it before)
2. Counter check 1 time

solutions.title: python3-step-by-step-hints-to-the-answer
solutions.content:
Understanding each **Operation** in the problem is the key to solving this problem, then thinking about if there are any **corner cases**. I made this post to hide everything first and let you open each hint and think through the problem to solve it yourself. (Code at the end)
Hint1: Operation 1
"Operation 1: Swap any two existing characters as many times as necessary." This means we can rearrange the word in any order. Try to rearrange 'abcb' to 'acdb' by swapping any two characters as many times as necessary.
Hint2: Operation 2
"Operation 2: Transform every occurrence of one existing character into another existing character, and do the same with the other character." This means the frequency of characters in each word needs to be the same. ```w1 = 'aaabb'``` is Close to ```w1 = 'bbbaa'``` because we just need to change all ```'a'``` to ```'b'```, and all ```'b'``` to ```'a'```.
Hint3: Corner case
What if a character in ```w1``` is not in ```w2```?
Algorithm
We will check the following 4 conditions: (1) frequency of characters in each word is the same. (2) unique characters in ```w1``` and ```w2``` are the same.
Code:
``` class Solution: def closeStrings(self, w1: str, w2: str) -> bool: f1 = Counter(w1) f2 = Counter(w2) return f1.keys()==f2.keys() and sorted(f1.values()) == sorted(f2.values()) ``` one-liner ``` class Solution: def closeStrings(self, w1: str, w2: str) -> bool: return (f1:=Counter(w1)) and (f2:=Counter(w2)) and len(w1) == len(w2) and f1.keys() == f2.keys() and sorted(f1.values()) == sorted(f2.values()) ``` Another one-liner, easy to understand but went through w1, w2 twice. ``` class Solution: def closeStrings(self, w1: str, w2: str) -> bool: return set(w1) == set(w2) and Counter(Counter(w1).values()) == Counter(Counter(w2).values()) ```
**Upvote** if you like this post. **Connect with me on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/meida-chen-938a265b/)** if you'd like to discuss other related topics Just in case if you are working on **ML/DL 3D data-related projects** or are interested in the topic, please check out our project **[HERE](https://github.com/meidachen/STPLS3D)**

solutions.content:
The first rule tells us that we don't have to worry about the order of the
characters in the strings.

The second rule tells us that we dont have to worry about which characters have
a certain count; only that there is a character with that count.

```python
def closeStrings(self, a, b):
	return set(a) == set(b) and Counter(Counter(a).values()) == Counter(Counter(b).values())
```

If `n` is the max length of `a` or `b`, then building and checking equality of
the sets runs in O(n) time. Building the first layer of the counts runs in O(n)
time, and takes O(n) space (If every character in the string is unique).
Building the second layer of the counts also runs in O(n) time, but only takes
O(sqrt(n)) space, since the worst case is that every chracter in the string has
a different count. Therefore checking equality of the counts runs in O(sqrt(n))
time.

This brings our total runtime complexity to O(n) + O(n) + O(n) + O(sqrt(n)),
which is just O(n), and our total space complexity to O(n) + O(n) + O(sqrt(n))
which is also O(n).
